data.title: DEATH OF FERDINAND RENAULT.
data.text:
The death of Ferdinand Renault in March, at the

age of 45, removed another of the trio of brothers

whose name has become famous throughout the world

and particularly so in London, where the little Renault

motorcabs set a fashion which is becoming general.

There were three brothers—Ferdinand, Marcel, and

Louis—the sons of a draper in Paris. Louis, the

[youngest, in 1896 abandoned the draper's counter yo

enter the Delaunay-Belleville establishment as a

draughtsman. The great, boiler firm at the time

was occupied solely with steam engines. In 1897

Louis Renault applied to Panhard-Levassor for a posi-

tion, and was bluntly informed that no amateurs were

wanted. The youth induced his mother to provide

him with a small workshop adjoining the house, where

he began the construction of cars. In 1898 the fac-

tory occupied an area of 230 square yards, employed

six workmen, and produced six cars within 12 months.

First success came in 1899, when the small vehicle,

won Paris—Rambouillet, Paris—Trouville, and Paris—

Ostend races. Marcel Renault, five years older than

his brother Louis, abandoned the drapery establishment,

for the motor car business about this time, and took

charge of the business department, at the same time

racing with the machines produced by his brother.

Gradually Ferdinand, the eldest of the three, be-

came interested in the business, and when Marcel

was killed in the Paris-Madrid race of 1903, he took

over the management.

Instead of six workmen, the Billancourt factory last

year had a staff of 2600, and an output of 5000 cars a

year. At 32 and 45 years of age respectively, the two

brothers were wealthy, both decorated with the Legion

of Honour, and at the head of one of the finest indus-

trial enterprises the world can boast.

The General Motor Company, Limited, are the local

representatives of Renault Freres.

GOULBURN, Friday.

The Amateur Bicycle Club's five miles road race this
